title: 'Stewards attacked' and 'objects thrown' between Birmingham and Leeds United fans at Elland Road
text:
The Football Association are likely to be called to investigate crowd disturbances at the end of the match between Leeds United and Birmingham City.

Objects were thrown between the two sets of supporters at Elland Road after the final whistle while videos showed punches being thrown at stewards by visiting fans.

Police made 11 arrests inside and outside the ground while several stewards suffered minor injuries.

Ugly scenes marred the end of Leeds' 1-0 win over Birmingham at Elland Road on Saturday

Objects were allegedly thrown between the fans and one steward apparently injured

Online footage appeared to show some fans goading police as they came into the stands

The ugly scenes then continued outside the ground where police horses were drafted in to keep rival fans apart in a tense stand-off which lasted for 45 minutes.

But West Yorkshire Police are appealing for witnesses to anyone who saw the disorder.

'Chief Inspector Jon Arrowsuch, Match Commander of the event, said: 'Our enquires are ongoing into the incidents which took place at this afternoon's game.

The ugly scenes also saw fans appearing to point and holler at police officers

Trouble at the end of the game with Birmingham fans looking to beat the row of police. Obviously leads to some back from Leeds fans too. pic.twitter.com/ZuG2SOGfSJ — Tom Carnduff (@TomC_22) October 19, 2019

'Police resources were deployed outside Elland Road and officers made 11 arrests in total for offences both inside and outside the ground.

'Clearly these were scenes no-one would wish to see and we will be examining CCTV footage and working with both clubs as we investigate what took place.'

Leeds will launch their own internal investigation with all stewards asked to make a written report of what they had witnessed.

They had won the match 1-0 on the occasion to mark the club's 100th anniversary, with Kalvin Phillips scoring the only goal of the game.

The midfielder latched onto Jack Harrison's through ball before slotting past Lee Camp in the Birmingham goal in the 65th minute of the match.

Birmingham had chances to equalise but Kiko Casilla stood firm in the Leeds goal and ensured the hosts sit second in the Championship table.
description: The Football Association could be called in to investigate the crowd disturbances that marred the end of the Championship match between Leeds United and Birmingham City.
